sp.p: Above all name to express it.

sp.speaker: Artes.
sp.p: Yet now the pleasure's gone, and you have lost your joys possession.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Yet when you please this flood may ebb again.

sp.speaker: Artes.
sp.p: But where it never ebbs, there runs the main.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Who can attain such hopes?

sp.speaker: Artes.
sp.p: Ile show the way to it, give me a taste once more of what you may enjoy.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Impudent whore! I were more false than Atheism can be, Should I not call this high felicity.

sp.speaker: Artes.
sp.p: If I should trust your faith, alas I fear you soon would change belief.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: I would covet Martyrdom to make't confirm'd.

sp.speaker: Artes.
sp.p: Give me your hand on that, you'l keep your word?

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: Artes.
sp.p: Enough: Help husband, king Aurelius, help, rescue betraid Artesia.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.l: Nay then 'tis I that am betraid I see,
Yet with thy blood Ile end thy Treachery.

sp.speaker: Artes.
sp.p: How now! what troubles you? Is this you sir, that but even now would suffer Martyrdom to win your hopes, and is there now such terror in names of men to fright you? nay then I see what mettle you are made on.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Ha! was it but tryal? then I ask your pardon: What a dull slave was I to be so fearful? Ile trust her now no more, yet try the utmost. I am resolved, no brother, no man breathing, were he my bloods begetter, should withhold me from your love, I'd leap into his bosom, and from his brest pull forth that happiness Heaven had reserved in you for my enjoying.

sp.speaker: Artes.
sp.p: I now you speak a Lover like a Prince: Treason, treason.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Agen.

sp.speaker: Artes.
sp.p: Help Saxon Princes: Treason.

sp.speaker: Ostor.
sp.p: Rescue the Queen: strike down the Villain.

div.stage: Enter Edoll, Aurelius, Donobert, Cador, Edwin, Toclio, Oswold, at the other Door.

sp.speaker: Edol.
sp.p: Call in the Guards: the Prince in danger! Fall back dear Sir, my brest shall buckler you.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.p: Beat down their weapons.

sp.speaker: Edol.
sp.p: Slave, wert thou made of brass, my sword shall bite thee.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.p: Withdraw on pain of death, where is the Traitor?

sp.speaker: Artes.
sp.p: Oh save your life, my Lord, let it suffice my beauty forc't mine own captivity.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.p: Who did attempt to wrong thee?

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Here me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.p: Oh my sad soul! was't thou?

sp.speaker: Artes.
sp.p: Oh do not stand to speak, one minutes stay, prevents a second speech for ever.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.p: Make our Guards strong: My dear Artesia, let us know thy wrongs, and our own dangers.

sp.speaker: Artes.
sp.p:
The Prince your brother, with these Brittain Lords, have all agreed to take me hence by force, and marry
me to him.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: The Devil shall wed thee first: thy baseness and thy lust confound and rot thee.

sp.speaker: Artes.
sp.p: He courted me even now, and in mine car sham'd not to plead his most dishonest love, and their attempts to seize your sacred person, either to shut you up within some prison, or which is worse, I fear to murther you.

sp.speaker: Omnes Brittains.
sp.p: 'Tis all as false as hell.

sp.speaker: Edol.
sp.p: And as foul as she is.

sp.speaker: Artes.
sp.p: You know me, Sir?

sp.speaker: Edol.
sp.p: Yes, Deadly Sin, we know you, and shall discover all your villany.

sp.speaker: Aurel
sp.p: Chester forbear.

sp.speaker: Ostor.
sp.p: Their treasons sir, are plain: Why are their Souldiers lodg'd so near the Court?

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.p: Nay, why came he in arms so suddenly?

sp.speaker: Edol.
sp.p: You fleering Anticks, do not wake my fury.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.p: Fury!

sp.speaker: Edol.
sp.p: Ratsbane, do not urge me.

sp.speaker: Artes.
sp.p: Good sir, keep farther from them.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Oh my sick heart, she is a witch by nature, devil by art.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.p: Bite thine own slanderous tongue, 'tis thou art false, I have observ'd your passions long ere this.

sp.speaker: Ostor.
sp.p: Stand on your guard, my Lord, we are your friends, and all our Force is yours.

sp.speaker: Edol.
sp.p: To spoil and rob the Kingdom.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.p: Sir, be silent.

sp.speaker: Edol.
sp.p: Silent! how long? till Doomsday? shall I stand by, and hear mine Honor blasted with foul Treason, the State half lost, and your life endanger'd, yet be silent?

sp.speaker: Artes.
sp.p: Yes, my blunt Lord, unless you speak your Treasons. Sir, let your Guards, as Traitors, seize them all, and then let tortures and devulsive racks, force a Confession from them.

sp.speaker: Edol.
sp.p: Wilde-fire and Brimstone eat thee. Hear me sir.

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.p: Sir, Ile not hear you.

sp.speaker: Edol.
sp.p: But you shall: Not hear me I were the worlds Monarch, Cesar, living, he should hear me. I tell you Sir, these serpents have betraid your Life and Kingdom: does not every day bring tidings of more swarms of lowsie slaves, the offal fugitives of barren Germany, that land upon our Coasts, and by our neglect settled in Norfolk and Northumberland?

sp.speaker: Ostor.
sp.p: They come as Aids and Safeguards to the King.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.p: Has he not need, when Vortiger's in arms, and you raise Powers, 'tis thought, to joyn with him?

sp.speaker: Edol.
sp.p: Peace, you pernicious Rat.

sp.speaker: Dono.
sp.p: Prithee forbear.

sp.speaker: Edol.
sp.p: Away, suffer a gilded rascal, a low-bred despicable creeper, an insulting Toad, to spit his poison'd venome in my face!

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.p: Sir, sir.

sp.speaker: Edol.
sp.p: Do not reply, you Cur, for by the Gods, tho' the Kings presence guard thee, I shall break all patience, and like a Lion rous'd to spoil, shall run foul-mouth'd upon thee, and devour thee quick. Speak sir, will you forsake these scorpions, or stay till they have stung you to the heart?

sp.speaker: Aurel.
sp.p: Y'are traitors all, this is our wife, our Queen: brother Ostorius, troop your Saxons up, we'l hence to Winchester, raise more powers, to man with strength the Castle Camilot: go hence false men, joyn you with Vortiger, the murderer of our brother Constantine: we'l hunt both him and you with dreadful vengance,
sp.l: Since Brittain fails, we'l trust to forrain friends,
And guard our person from your traitorous ends.

div.stage: Exeunt Aurel. Ostor. Octa. Artes. Toc. Osw.

sp.speaker: Edwin.
sp.p: He's sure bewitch.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.p: What counsel now for safety?

sp.speaker: Dono.
sp.p: Onely this sir, with all the speed we can, preserve the person of the King and Kingdom.

sp.speaker: Cador.
sp.p: Which to effect, tis best march hence to Wales, and set on Vortiger before he joyn his Forces with the Saxons,

sp.speaker: Edwin.
sp.p: On then with speed for Wales and Vortiger, that tempest once o'reblown, we come Ostorius to meet thy traiterous Saxons, thee and them, that with advantage thus have won the King, to back your factions, and to work our ruines.
sp.l: This by the Gods and my good Sword, I'le set
In bloody lines upon thy Burgonet.

div.head: ACT. 4. SCENE. 1.
div.stage: Enter Clown, Merlin, and a little antick Spirit.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: HOw now Uncle, why do you search your pockets so? do you miss any thing?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Ha, Cousin Merlin, I hope your beard does not overgrow your honesty, I pray remember you are made up of sisters thread, I am your mothers brother, whosoever was your father.

sp.speaker: Merlin.
sp.p: Why, wherein can you task my duty, Uncle?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p:
Your self, or your page it must be, I have kept no other company, since your mother bound your head to my Protectorship, I do feel a fault of one side, either it was that Sparrowhawk, or a Cast of Merlins, for I finde a Covy
of Cardecu's sprung out of my pocket.

sp.speaker: Merlin.
sp.p: Why, do you want any money Uncle? sirrah, had you any from him?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Deny it not, for my pockets are witness against you.

sp.speaker: Spirit.
sp.p: Yes I had, to teach you better wit to look to it.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Pray use your fingers better, and my wit may serve as it is sir.

sp.speaker: Merlin.
sp.p: Well, restore it.

sp.speaker: Spirit.
sp.p: There it is.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: I, there's some honestly in this, 'twas a token from your invisible Father Cousin, which I would not have to go invisibly from me agen.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Well, you are sure you have it now Uncle?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Yes, and mean to keep it now, from your pages filching fingers too.

sp.speaker: Spirit.
sp.p: If you have it so sure, pray show it me agen.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Yes, my little juggler, I dare show it, ha, cleanly conveyance agen, ye have no invisible fingers have ye? 'Tis gone certainly.

sp.speaker: Spirit.
sp.p: Why sir, I toucht you not.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Why look you Uncle, I have it now, how ill do you look to it? here keep it safer.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Ha, ha, this is fine yfaith, I must keep some other company if you have these slights of hand.

sp.speaker: Merlin.
sp.p: Come, come, Uncle, 'tis all my Art which shall not offend you sir, onely I give you a taste of it, to show you sport.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Oh, but 'tis ill jesting with a mans pocket tho'— but I am glad to see you cunning Cousin, for now will I warrant thee a living till thou diest. You have heard the news in Wales here?

sp.speaker: Mer
sp.p: Uncle, let me prevent your care and counsel, 'twill give you better knowledge of my cunning, you would prefer me now in hope of gain, to Vortiger King of the Welch Brittains, to whom are all the Artists summon'd now, that seeks the secrets of futurity, the Bards, the Druids, Wizards, Conjurers, not an Aurasper with his
sp.l: Whisling spells, no Capuomanster with his musty fumes,
No Witch or Juggler, but is thither sent,
To calculate the strange and fear'd event
sp.p: Of his prodigious Castle now in building, where all the labors of the painful day, are ruin'd still ith' night, and to this place you would have me go.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Well, if thy mother were not my sister, I would say she was a witch that begot this; but this is thy father, not thy mother wit, thou hast taken my tale into thy mouth, and spake my thoughts before me; therefore away, shuffle thy self amongst the Conjurers, and be a made man before thou comest to age.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
Nay, but stay Uncle, you overslip my dangers:
the Prophecies and all the cunning Wizards, have certifi'd the King, that this his Castle can never stand, till the foundation's laid with Mortar temper'd with the fatal blood of such a childe, whose father was no mortal.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: What's this to thee? If the devil were thy father, was not thy mother born at Carmarden? Diggon for that then, and then it must be a childes blood, and who will take thee for a childe with such a beard of thy face? Is there not diggon for that too Cousin?

sp.speaker: Merlin.
sp.p: I must not go, lend me your ear a while, I'le give you reasons to the contrary.

sp.speaker: 1 Gentle.
sp.p: Sure this is an endless piece of work the King has sent us about!

sp.speaker: 2 Gentle.
sp.p: Kings may do it, man, the like has been done to finde out the Unicorn.

sp.speaker: 1 Gentle.
sp.p: Which will be sooner found I think, then this fien'd begotten childe we seek for.

sp.speaker: 2 Gentle.
sp.p: Pox of those Conjurers that would speak of such a one, and yet all their cunning could not tell us where to finde him.

sp.speaker: 1 Gentle.
sp.p: In Wales they say assuredly he lives, come let's enquire further.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Uncle, your perswasions must not prevail with me, I know mine enemies better then you do.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: I say th'art a bastard then if thou disobey thine Uncle, was not Ioan Go-too't thy mother, my sister? if the devil were thy father, what kin art thou to any man alive, but Bailys and Brokers? and they are but brothers in Law to thee neither.

sp.speaker: 1 Gentle.
sp.p: How's this, I think we shall speed here.

sp.speaker: 2 Gentle.
sp.p: I, and unlook't for too, go ne're and listen to them.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Hast thou a beard to hide it, wil't thou show thy self a childe, wil't thou have more hair then wit? Wil't thou deny thy mother, because no body knows thy father? Or shall thine Uncle be an ass?

sp.speaker: 1 Gentle.
sp.p: Bless ye friend, pray what call you this small Gentlemans name?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Small, sir, a small man may be a great Gentleman, his father may be of an ancient house, for ought we know sir.

sp.speaker: 2 Gentle.
sp.p: Why? do you not know his father?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: No, nor you neither I think, unless the devil be in ye.

sp.speaker: 1 Gentle.
sp.p: What is his name sir?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: His name is my Cousin sir, his education is my sisters son, but his maners are his own.

sp.speaker: Merlin.
sp.p: Why ask ye Gentlemen? my name is Merlin.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Yes, and a Goshawk was his father, for ought we know, for I am sure his mother was a Wind-sucker.

sp.speaker: 2 Gentle.
sp.p: He has a mother then?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p:
As sure
as I have a sister, sir.

sp.speaker: 1 Gentle.
sp.p: But his father you leave doubtful.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Well Sir, as wise men as you, doubt whether he had a father or no?

sp.speaker: 1 Gentle.
sp.p: Sure this is he we seek for.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: I think no less: and sir, we let you know the King hath sent for you.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: The more childe he, and he had bin rul'd by me, he should have gone before he was sent for.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: May we not see his mother?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Yes, and feel her too if you anger her, a devilish thing I can tell ye she has been, Ile go fetch her to ye.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: Sir, it were fit you did resolve for speed, you must unto the King.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: My Service sir, shall need no strict command, it shall obey most peaceably, but needless 'tis to fetch what is brought home, my journey may be staid, the King is coming hither with the same quest you bore before him, hark, this drum will tell ye.

div.stage: Within Drums beat a low March.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.l: This is some cunning indeed sir.

div.stage: Florish. Enter Vortiger reading a letter, Proximus, with Drum and Soldiers, &c.

sp.speaker: Vorti.
sp.p: Still in our eye your message Proximus, we keep to spur our speed: Ostorius, and Octa, we shall salute with succor against Prince Vter and Aurelius, whom now we hear incamps at Winchester, there's nothing interrupts our way so much, as doth the erection of this fatal Castle, that spite of all our Art and daily labor, the night still ruines.

sp.speaker: Prox.
sp.p: As erst I did affirm, still I maintain, the fien'd begotten childe must be found out, whose blood gives strength to the foundation, it cannot stand else.

sp.speaker: Vorti.
sp.p: Ha! I'st so? then Proximus by this intelligence he should be found: speak, is this he you tell of?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Yes Sir, and I his Uncle, and she his mother.

sp.speaker: Vorti.
sp.p: And who is his father?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Why, she his mother can best tell you that, and yet I think the childe be wise enough, for he has found his father.

sp.speaker: Vort.
sp.p: Woman, is this thy son?

sp.speaker: Ioan.
sp.p: It is, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.p: What was his father? Or where lives he?

sp.speaker: Merl.
sp.l: Mother speak freely and unastonisht,
That which you dar'd to act, dread not to name.

sp.speaker: Ioan.
sp.l: In which I shall betray my sin and shame,
sp.p:
But since it must be so, then know great King, all that my self yet
knows of him, is this: In pride of blood and beauty I did live, my glass the Altar was, my face the Idol, such was my peevish love unto my self, that I did hate all other, such disdain was in my scornful eye, that I suppos'd no mortal creature worthy to enjoy me, thus with the Peacock I beheld my train, but never saw the blackness of my feet, oft have I child the winds for breathing on me, and curst the Sun, fearing to blast my beauty, in midst of this most leaprous disease, a seeming fair yong man appear'd unto me, in all things suiting my aspiring pride, and with him brought along a conquering power, to which my frailty yielded, from whose embraces this issue came, what more he is, I know not.

sp.speaker: Vorti.
sp.p: Some Incubus, or Spirit of the night begot him then, for sure no mortal did it.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: No matter who my Lord, leave further quest, since 'tis as hurtful as unnecessary more to enquire: Go to the cause my Lord, why you have sought me thus?

sp.speaker: Vorti.
sp.p: I doubt not but thou knowst, yet to be plain, I sought thee for thy blood.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: By whose direction?

sp.speaker: Prox.
sp.p: By mine, my Art infalable instructed me, upon thy blood must the foundation rise of the Kings building, it cannot stand else.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Hast thou such leisure to enquire my Fate, and let thine own hang careless over thee? Knowst thou what pendelous mischief roofs thy head, how fatal, and how sudden?

sp.speaker: Prox.
sp.p: Pish, bearded abortive, thou foretel my danger my Lord, he trifles to delay his own.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: No, I yield my self: and here before the King, make good thine Augury, as I shall mine, if thy fate fall not, thou hast spoke all truth, and let my blood satisfie the Kings desires: if thou thy self wilt write thine Epitaph, dispatch it quickly, there's not a minutes time 'twixt thee and thy death.

div.stage: A stone falls and kills Proximus.

sp.speaker: Prox.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: I, so, thou mayest die laughing.

sp.speaker: Vorti.
sp.p: Ha! This is above admiration, look, is he dead?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Yes sir, here's brains to make morter on, if you'l use them: Cousin Merlin, there's no more of this stone fruit ready to fall, is there? I pray give your Uncle a little fair warning.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
Remove that shape of death, and now my Lord for clear satisfaction of your doubts, Merlin will show the fatal cause that keeps your fatal Castle down, and hinders your proceedings: Stand there, and by an apparition see the labor and end of all your destiny.
Mother and Uncle, you must be absent.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Is your father coming Cousin?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Nay, you must be gone.

sp.speaker: Ioan
sp.p: Come, you'l offend him brother.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: I would fain see my Brother i'law, if you were married I might lawfully call him so.

div.stage: Thunder and Lightning, two Dragons appear, a White and a Red, they fight a while and pause.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.p: What means this stay?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Be not amaz'd my Lord, for on the victory
Of loss or gain, as these two Champions ends
Your fate, your life, and kingdom all depends,
therefore observe it well.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.p: I shall, heaven be auspicious to us.

div.stage: Thunder: The two Dragons fight agen, and the White Dragon drives off the Red.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.p: The conquest is on the white Dragons part, now Merlin faithfully expound the meaning.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Your Grace must then not be offended with me.

sp.speaker: Vor.
sp.p: It is the weakest part I found in thee, to doubt of me so slightly, shall I blame my prophet that foretells me of my dangers? thy cunning I approve most excellent.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Then know my Lord, there is a dampish Cave, the nightly habitation of these Dragons, vaulted beneath where you would build your Castle, whose enmity and nightly combats there, maintain a constant ruine of your labors: To make it more plain, the Dragons then your self betoken, and the Saxon King, the vanquisht Red, is sir, your dreadful Emblem.

sp.speaker: Vort.
sp.p: Oh my fate!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Nay, you must hear with patience Royal sir, you slew the lawful King Constantius, 'twas a red deed, your Crown his blood did cement, the English Saxon first brought in by you, for aid against Constantius brethren, is the white horror who now knit together, have driven and shut you up in these wilde mountains, and though they now seek to unite with friendship, it is to wound your bosom, not embrace it, and with an utter extirpation to rout the Brittains out, and plant the English. Seek for your safety Sir, and spend no time to build the airy Castles, for Prince Vter armed with vengeance for his brothers blood is hard upon you, if you mistrust me, and to my words craves witness sir, then know here comes a messenger to tell you so.

sp.speaker: Messen.
sp.p: My Lord Prince Uter!

sp.speaker: Vort.
sp.p: And who else sir?

sp.speaker: Messen.
sp.p: Edol, the great General.

sp.speaker: Vort.
sp.p: The great Devil, they are coming to meet us.

sp.speaker: Messen.
sp.p: With a full power my Lord.

sp.speaker: Vort.
sp.p: With a full vengeance they mean to meet us, so we are ready to their confront as full march double footing, we'l loose no ground, nor shall their numbers fright us,
sp.l: If it be Fate, it cannot be withstood,
We got our Crown so, be it lost in blood.

div.stage: Enter Prince Vter, Edol, Cador, Edwin, Toclio, with Drum and Soldiers.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Stay, and advice, hold drum.

sp.speaker: Edol.
sp.p: Beat slave, why do you pause? why make a stand? where are our enemies? or do you mean we fight amongst our selves?

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Nay, noble Edol, let us here take counsel, it cannot hurt, it is the surest Garison to safety.

sp.speaker: Edol.
sp.p: Fie on such slow delays! so fearful men that are to pass over a flowing river, stand on the bank to parly of the danger, till the tide rise and then be swallowed, is not the King in field?

sp.speaker: Cador.
sp.p: Proud Vortiger, the Trator is in field.

sp.speaker: Edwin.
sp.p: The Murderer, and Usurper.

sp.speaker: Edol.
sp.p: Let him be the devil so I may fight with him, for heavens love sir march on, oh my patience, will you delay untill the Saxons come to aid his party? A Tucket.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: There's no such fear, prithee be calm a while, hark, it seems by this, he comes or sends to us.

sp.speaker: Edol.
sp.p: If it be for parly, I will drown the summons, if all our drums and hoarseness choke me me not.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Nay, prithee hear, from whence art thou?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: From the King Vortiger.

sp.speaker: Edol.
sp.p: Traitor, there's none such: Alarum drum, strike slave, or by mine honor I will break thy head, and beat thy drums heads both about thine ears.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Hold noble Edol, let's hear what Articles he can inforce.

sp.speaker: Edol.
sp.p: What articles, or what conditions can you expect to value half your wrong, unless he kill himself by thousand tortures, and send his carcase to appease your vengeance, for the foul murder of Constantius, and that's not a tenth part neither. Prince 'Tis true, my brothers blood is crying to me now, I do applaud thy counsel: hence, be gone.
We'l hear no parly now but by our swords.

sp.speaker: Edol.
sp.p: And those shall speak home in death killing words, Alarum to the fight, sound, sound the Alarum.

div.stage: Alarum. Enter Edol driving all Vortigers Force before him, then Enter Prince Vter pursuing Vortiger.

sp.speaker: Vort.
sp.p: Dost follow me?

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Yes, to thy death I will.

sp.speaker: Vort.
sp.p: Stay, be advis'd, I would not be the onely fall of Princes, I slew thy brother:

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Thou didst black Traitor, and in that vengeance I pursue thee.

sp.speaker: Vort.
sp.p: Take mercy for thy self, and flie my sword, save thine own life as satisfaction, which here I give thee for thy brothers death.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Give what's thine own: a Traitors heart and head, that's all thou art right Lord of; the Kingdom which thou usurp'st, thou most unhappy Tyrant, is leaving thee, the Saxons which thou broughtst to back thy usurpations, are grown great, and where they seat themselves, do hourly seek to blot the Records of old Brute and Brittains, from memory of men, calling themselves Hingest-men, and Hingest-land, that no more the Brittain name be known; all this by thee, thou base destroyer of thy Native Countrey.

sp.speaker: Edol.
sp.p: What, stand you talking? Fight.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Hold Edol.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.p: Hold out my sword, and listen not to King or Princes word, There's work enough abroad, this task is mine.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Prosper thy Valour, as thy Vertues shine.

sp.speaker: Cador.
sp.p: Bright Victory her self fights on our part, and buckled in a golden Beaver, rides triumphantly before us.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.p: Justice is with her, who ever takes the true and rightful cause, let us not lag behinde them.

sp.speaker: Cador.
sp.p: Here comes the Prince, how goes our fortunes Sir?

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Hopeful, and fair, brave Cador, proud Vortiger beat down by Edols sword, was rescu'd by the following multitudes, and now for safety's fled unto a Castle here standing on the hill: but I have sent a cry of hounds as violent as hunger, to break his stony walls, or if they fail,
sp.l: We'l send in wilde fire to dislodge him thence,
Or burn them all with flaming violence.

div.stage: Florish Tromp. Enter Prince, Vter, Edol, Cador, Edwin, Toclio with with Drum and Soldiers.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.p: Look Edol: still this fiery exalation shoots his frightful horrors on th'amazed world, see in the beam that 'bout his flaming ring, a Dragons head appears, from out whose mouth two flaming flakes of fire, stretch East and West.

sp.speaker: Edol.
sp.p: And see, from forth the body of the Star, seven smaller blazing streams, directly point on this affrighted kingdom.

sp.speaker: Cador.
sp.p: 'Tis a dreadful Meteor.

sp.speaker: Edwin.
sp.p: And doth portend strange fears.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: This is no Crown of Peace, this angry fire hath something more to burn then Vortiger; if it alone were pointed at his fall; it would pull in his blasing Piramids, and be appeas'd, for Vortiger is dead.

sp.speaker: Edol.
sp.p: These never come without their large effects.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: The will of heaven be done, our sorrows this we want, a mistick Pithon to expound this fiery Oracle.

sp.speaker: Cador.
sp.p: Oh no my Lord, you have the best that ever Brittain bred, and durst I prophecy of your Prophet sir, none like him shall succeed him.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: You mean Merlin.

sp.speaker: Cador.
sp.p: True sir, wonderous Merlin, he met us in the way, and did foretell the fortunes of this day successful to us.

sp.speaker: Edwin.
sp.p: He's sure about the Camp, send for him sir.

sp.speaker: Cador.
sp.p: He told the bloody Vortiger his fate, and truely too, and if I could give faith to any Wizards skill, it should be Merlin.

sp.speaker: Cador.
sp.p: And see my Lord, as if to satisfie your Highness pleasure, Merlin is come.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: See, the Comet's in his eye, disturb him nor.

sp.speaker: Edol.
sp.p: With what a piercing judgement he beholds it!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Whither will Heaven and Fate translate this Kingdom? what revolutions, rise and fall of Nations
sp.l: Is figur'd yonder in that Star, that sings
The change of Brittains State, and death of Kings?
Ha! He's dead already, how swiftly mischief creeps!
Thy fatal end sweet Prince, even Merlin weeps.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: He does foresee some evil, his action shows it, for e're he does expound, he weeps the story.

sp.speaker: Edol.
sp.p: There's another weeps too. Sirrah dost thou understand what thou lamentst for?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: No sir, I am his Uncle, and weep because my Cousin weeps, flesh and blood cannot forbear.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p:
Gentle Merlin, speak thy prophetick knowledge, in explanation of this fiery horror, from which we gather from thy mournful tears, much sorrow
and disaster in it.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: 'Tis true fair Prince, but you must hear the rest with patience.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: I vow I will, tho' it portend my ruine.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: There's no such fear, this brought the fiery fall of Vortiger, and yet not him alone, this day is faln a King more good, the glory of our Land, the milde, and gentle, sweet Aurelius.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Our brother!

sp.speaker: Edwin.
sp.p: Forefend it heaven.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: He at his Palace Royal sir at Winchester, this day is dead and poison'd.

sp.speaker: Cador.
sp.p: By whom? Or what means Merlin?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: By the Traiterous Saxons.

sp.speaker: Edol.
sp.p: I ever fear'd as much: that devil Ostorius, and the damn'd witch Artesia, sure has done it.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Poison'd! oh look further gentle Merlin, behold the Star agen, and do but finde revenge for me, though it cost thousand lives, and mine the foremost.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Comfort your self, the heavens have given it fully, all the portentious ills to you is told, now hear a happy story sir from me, to you and to your fair posterity.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Me thinks I see something like a peel'd Oinon, it makes me weep agen.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Be silent Uncle, you'l be forc't else.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Can you not finde in the Star, Cousin, whether I can hold my tongue or no?

sp.speaker: Edol.
sp.p: Yes, I must cut it out.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Phu, you speak without book sir, my Cousin Merlin knows.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: True, I must tie it up, now speak your pleasure Uncle.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Hum, hum, hum, hum.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: So, so— now observe my Lord, and there behold above yon flame-hair'd beam that upward shoots, appears a Dragons head, out of whose mouth two streaming lights point their flame-feather'd darts contrary ways, yet both shall have their aims: Again behold from the ignifirent body, seven splendant and illustrious rays are spred, all speaking Heralds to this Brittain Isle, and thus they are expounded: The Dragons head is the Herogliphick that figures out your Princely self, that here must reign a King, those by-form'd fires that from the Dragons mouth shoot East and West, emblem two Royal babes, which shall proceed from you, a son and daughter: her pointed constellation Northwest bending,
Crowns Her a Queen in Ireland, of whom first springs
That Kingdoms Title to the Brittain Kings.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Hum, hum, hum.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
But of your Son, thus Fate and Merlin tells, all after times shall fill their Chronicles with fame of his renown, whose warlike sword shall pass through fertile France
and Germany, nor shall his conjuring foot be forc't to stand, till Romes Imperial Wreath hath crown'd his Fame with Monarch of the West, from whose seven hills with Conquest, and contributory Kings, he back returns to inlarge the Brittain bounds, his Heraldry adorn'd with thirteen Crowns.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Hum, hum, hum.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: He to the world shall add another Worthy, and as a Loadstone for his prowess, draw a train of Marshal Lovers to his Court: It shall be then the best of Knight-hoods honor, at Winchester to fill his Castle Hall, and at his Royal Table sit and feast in warlike orders, all their arms round hurl'd, as if they meant to circumscribe the world.

div.stage: [he touches the Clowns mouth with his wand

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Hum, hum, hum, oh that I could speak a little.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: I know your mind Uncle, agen be silent.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Thou speakst of wonders Merlin, prithee go on, declare at full this Constellation.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Those seven beams pointing downward, sir, betoken the troubles of this Land, which then shall meet with other Fate; War and Dissension strives to make division, till seven Kings agree to draw this Kingdom to a Hepterchy.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Thine art hath made such proof, that we believe thy words authentical, be ever neer us, my Prophet, and the Guide of all my actions.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: My service shall be faithful to your person, and all my studies for my Countries safety.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Hum, hum, hum.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Come, you are releast, sir.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Cousin, pray help me to my tongue agen, you do not mean I shall be dumb still I hope?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Why, hast thou not thy tongue?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Ha! yes, I feel it now, I was so long dumb, I could not well tell whether I spake or no.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: I'st thy advice we presently pursue the bloody Saxons, that have slain my brother?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: With your best speed, my Lord, Prosperity will keep you company.

sp.speaker: Cador.
sp.p: Take then your Title with you, Royal Prince, 'twill adde unto our strength, Long live King Uter.

sp.speaker: Edol.
sp.p: Put the Addition to't that Heaven hath given you: The DRAGON is your Emblem, bear it bravely, and so long live and ever happy styl'd Vter-Pendragon, lawful King of Brittain.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Thanks Edol, we imbrace the name and title, and in our Sheild and Standard shall the figure of a Red Dragon still be born before us, to fright the bloody Saxons. Oh my Aurelius, sweet rest thy soul; let thy disturbed spirit
sp.l: Expect revenge, think what it would, it hath,
The Dragon's coming in his fiery wrath.

div.head: ACT. 5. SCENE. 1.
div.stage: Enter Ioan fearfully, the Devil following her.

sp.speaker: Ioan.
sp.p: HEnce thou black horror, is thy lustful fire kindled agen? not thy loud throated thunder, nor thy adulterate infernal Musick, shall e're bewitch me more, oh too too much is past already.

sp.speaker: Devil.
sp.p: Why dost thou fly me? I come a Lover to thee, to imbrace, and gently twine thy body in mine arms.

sp.speaker: Ioan.
sp.p: Out thou Hell-hound.

sp.speaker: Devil.
sp.l: What hound so e're I be,
Fawning and sporting as I would with thee,
sp.p: why should I not be stroakt and plaid withal, will't thou not thank the Lion might devour thee, if he shall let thee pass?

sp.speaker: Ioan.
sp.p: Yes, thou art he, free me, and Ile thank thee.

sp.speaker: Devil.
sp.p: Why, whither wouldst? I am at home with thee, thou art mine own, have we not charge of family together, where is your son?

sp.speaker: Ioan.
sp.p: Oh darkness cover me.

sp.speaker: Devil.
sp.p: There is a pride which thou hast won by me, the mother of a fame shall never die, Kings shall have need of written Chronicles, to keep their names alive, but Merlin none, ages to ages shall like Sabalists
sp.l: Report the wonders of his name and glory,
While there are tongues and times to tell his story.

sp.speaker: Ioan.
sp.p: Oh rot my memory before my flesh, let him be called some hell or earth-bred monster, that ne're had hapless woman for a mother: sweet death deliver me, hence from my sight, why shouldst thou now appear? I had no pride nor lustful thought about me, to conjure and call thee to my ruine, when as at first thy cursed person became visible.

sp.speaker: Devil.
sp.p: I am the same I was.

sp.speaker: Ioan.
sp.p: But I am chang'd.

sp.speaker: Devil.
sp.p: Agen Ile change thee to the same thou wert, quench to my lust, come forth by thunder led, my Coajutors in the spoils of mortals.

Claspe in your Ebon arms that prize of mine, mount her as high as palled Hecate, and on this rock Ile stand to cast up fumes and darkness o're the blew fac'd firmament; from Brittain, and from Merlin, Ile remove her, they ne're shall meet agen.

sp.speaker: Ioan.
sp.p: Help me some saving hand, if not too late, I cry let mercy come.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Stay you black slaves of night, let loose your hold, set her down safe, or by th'infernal Stix, Ile binde you up with exorcisms so strong, that all the black pentagoron of hell, shall ne're release you, save you selves and vanish.

sp.speaker: Devil,
sp.p: Ha! What's he?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: The Childe has found his Father, do you not know me?

sp.speaker: Devil.
sp.p: Merlin!

sp.speaker: Ioan.
sp.p: Oh, help me gentle son.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Fear not, they shall not hurt you.

sp.speaker: Devil.
sp.p: Relievest thou her to disobey thy father?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Obedience is no lesson in your school, nature and kind to her, commands my duty, the part that you begot was against kinde, so all I ow to you is to be unkind.

sp.speaker: Devil.
sp.p: Ile blast thee slave to death, and on this rock stick thee an eternal Monument.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Ha, ha, thy powers too weak, what art thou devil, but an inferior lustful Incubus, taking advantage of the wanton flesh, wherewith thou dost beguile the ignorant? put off the form of thy humanity, and cral upon thy speckled belly, serpent, or Ile unclasp the jaws of Achoron, and fix thee ever in the local fire.

sp.speaker: Devil.
sp.p: Traitor to hell; curse that I e're begot thee.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Thou didst beget thy scourge, storm not, nor stir, the power of Merlins Art is all confirm'd in the Fates decretals,— Ile ransack hell, and make thy [Thunder and Lighting in the Rock .masters bow unto my spells, thou first shall taste it,— Tenibrarum precis, devitiarum, & infirorum, Deus, hunc Incubum in ignis eterni abisum, accipite aut in hoc carcere tenebroso, in sempeternum astringere mando. [the Rock incloses him. ]So, there beget earthquakes or some noisom damps, for never shalt thou touch a woman more: How chear you mother?

sp.speaker: Ioan.
sp.p: Oh now my son is my deliverer, yet I must name him with my deepest sorrow.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p:
Take comfort now, past times are ne're recal'd, I did foresee your mischief and prevent it: hark, how the sounds
of war now call me hence to aid Pendragon, that in battail stands against the Saxons, from whose aid Merlin must not be absent: leave this soyl, and Ile conduct you to a place retir'd, which I by art have rais'd, call'd Merlins Bower, there shall you dwell with solitary sighs, with grones and passions your companions, to weep away this flesh you have offended with, and leave all bare unto your aierial soul, and when you die, I will erect a Monument upon the verdant Plains of Salisbury, no King shall have so high a sepulchre, with pendulous stones that I will hang by art, where neither Lime nor Morter shalbe us'd, a dark Enigma to the memory, for none shall have the power to number them, a place that I will hollow for your rest,
sp.l: Where no Night-hag shall walk, nor Ware-wolf tread,
Where Merlins Mother shall be sepulcher'd.

sp.speaker: Dono.
sp.p: Sincerely Gloster, I have told you all: My Daughters are both vow'd to Single Life, and this day gone unto the Nunnery, though I begot them to another end, and fairly promis'd them in Marriage, one to Earl Cador, t'other to your son, my worthy friend, the Earl of Gloster. Those lost, I am lost: they are lost, all's lost. Answer me this then, Ist a sin to marry?

sp.speaker: Hermit.
sp.p: Oh no, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Dono.
sp.p: Go to then, Ile go no further with you, I perswade you to no ill, perswade you then that I perswade you well.

sp.speaker: Gloster.
sp.p: 'Twill be a good Office in you, sir.

sp.speaker: Dono.
sp.p: Which since they thus neglect, my memory shall lose them now for ever. See, see the Noble Lords, their promis'd Husbands! had Fate so pleas'd, you might have call'd me Father.

sp.speaker: Edwin.
sp.p: Those hopes are past, my Lord, for even this minute we saw them both enter the Monastery, secluded from the world and men for ever.

sp.speaker: Cador.
sp.p: 'Tis both our griefs we cannot, Sir: but from the King take you the Times joy from us; The Saxon King Ostorius slain, and Octa fled, that Woman-fury, Queen Artesia, is fast in hold, and forc't to re-deliver London and Winchester (which she had fortifi'd) to Princely Vter, lately styl'd Pendragon, who now triumphantly is marching hither to be invested with the Brittain Crown.

sp.speaker: Dono.
sp.p: The joy of this, shall banish from my breast all thought that I was Father to two Children, two stubborn Daughters, that have left me thus: Let my old arms embrace, and call you Sons, for by the Honor of my Fathers House, I'le part my estate most equally betwixt you.

sp.speaker: Edwin. Cador.
sp.p: Sir, y'are most noble!

div.stage: Flor. Tromp. Enter Edol with Drum and Colours, Oswold bearing the Standard, Toclio the Sheild, with the Red Dragon pictur'd in'em, two Bishops with the Crown, Prince Vter, Merlin, Artesia bound, Guard and Clown.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Set up our Sheild and Standard, noble Soldiers, We have firm hope that tho' our Dragon sleep, Merlin will us and our fair Kingdom keep.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: As his Uncle lives, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Glost.
sp.p: Happy Restorer of the Brittains fame, uprising Sun let us salute thy glory, ride in a day perpetual about us, and no night be in thy thrones zodiack, why do we stay to binde those Princely browes with this Imperial Honor?

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Stay noble Gloster, that monster first must be expel'd our eye, or we shall take no joy in it.

sp.speaker: Dono.
sp.p: If that be hindrance, give her quick Judgement, and send her hence to death, she has long deserv'd it.

sp.speaker: Edol.
sp.p: Let my Sentence stand for all, take her hence, and stake her carcase in the burning Sun, till it be parcht and dry, and then fley off her wicked skin, and stuff the pelt with straw to be shown up and down at Fairs and Markets, two pence a piece to see so foul a Monster, will be a fair Monopoly and worth the begging.

sp.speaker: Artes.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Edol.
sp.p: Dost laugh Erictho?

sp.speaker: Artes.
sp.p: Yes, at thy poor invention, is there no better, torturemonger?

sp.speaker: Dono.
sp.p: Burn her to dust.

sp.speaker: Artes.
sp.p: That's a Phaenix death, and glorious.

sp.speaker: Edol.
sp.p: I, that's to good for her.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Alive she shall be buried circled in a wall, thou murdress of a King, there starve to death.

sp.speaker: Artes.
sp.p: Then Ile starve death when he comes for his prey, and i'th' mean time Ile live upon your curses.

sp.speaker: Edol
sp.p: I, 'tis diet good enough, away with her.

sp.speaker: Artes.
sp.l: With joy, my best of wishes is before,
Thy brother's poison'd, but I wanted more.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Why does our Prophet Merlin stand apart, sadly observing these our Ceremonies, and not applaud our joys with thy hid knowledge? Let thy divining Art now satisfie some part of my desires; for well I know 'tis in thy power to show the full event, that shall both end our Reign and Chronicle: speak learned Merlin, and resolve my feats, whether by war we shall expel the Saxons, or govern what we hold with beauteous peace in Wales and Brittain?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: Long happiness attend Pendragons Reign, what Heaven decrees, fate hath no power to alter: The Saxons, sir, will keep the ground they have, and by supplying numbers still inccrease, till Brittain be no more. So please your Grace, I will in visible apparitions, present you Prophecies which shall concern
sp.l: Succeeding Princes, which my Art shall raise,
Till men shall call these times the latter days.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Do it my Merlin, and Crown me with much joy and wonder.

div.stage: Hoeboys. Enter a King in Armour, his Sheild quarter'd with thirteen Crowns. At the other door enter divers Princes who present their Crowns to him at his feet, and do him homage, then enters Death and strikes him, he growing sick, Crowns Constantine.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.p: This King, my Lord, presents your Royal Son, who in his prime of years shall be so fortunate, that thirteen several Princes, shall present their several Crowns unto him, and all Kings else shall so admire his fame and victories, that they shall all be glad either through fear or love, to do him homage; But death (who neither favors the weak nor valliant) in the middest of all his glories, soon shall seize him, scarcely permitting him to appoint one in all his purchased Kingdoms to succeed him.

sp.speaker: Prince.
sp.p: Thanks to our Prophet for this so wish'd for satisfaction, and hereby now we learn that always Fate must be observ'd, what ever that decree,
sp.l: All future times shall still record this Story,
Of Merlin's learned worth, and Arthur's glory.
